item.title: India’s depository duopoly: CDSL vs NSDL explained

review.headline_rewrite: India’s depository duopoly: CDSL vs NSDL explained
bullets: From market share to profitability, the contrast shows why one clearly stands stronger.
India’s depository industry is dominated by two giants, NSDL (NSE-backed) and CDSL (BSE-backed), forming a tight duopoly.
Instead of holding physical share certificates, which were vulnerable to loss, theft or damage, a depository keeps your shares, mutual fund, bonds, ETFs, and
Corporate actions: Executes the credit of dividends, bonuses, splits, and interest payments to the investor's account.

item.title: RBL Bank to CDSL- Prashanth Tapse of Mehta Equities suggests stocks to buy in the short term

review.headline_rewrite: RBL Bank to CDSL- Prashanth Tapse of Mehta Equities suggests stocks to buy in the short term
bullets: Stocks market today: Indian stocks retraced early gains on Friday as profit-taking in consumer shares and a decline in information technology offset a surge
The NSE Nifty 50 slid 0.03% to 24,724.1, while the BSE Sensex decreased 0.13% to 80,608.99 at 10:32 a.m.
Prashanth Tapse recommends buying these three stocks in the short term - RBL Bank, BSE, and CDSL.
Traders may consider fresh long positions with a stop-loss at ₹260 to manage downside risk effectively.
